div.p: Greetings in the Lord. I have nothing at this time to write; what was being circulated among us, I wrote about in those days, and I believe you have received my letters from a certain citizen of Zurich. What is happening in Saxony, you can inquire about most diligently from the courier.
Magdeburg is being besieged very severely; so writes someone to me; the letters are dated May 29: "Three days ago, they fought fiercely; skirmishes are held almost daily.
The army is seen again near LÃ¼neburg; against whom, it is unknown. Saxony will be greatly disturbed this year.
Many omens are seen; there is great despair among people, many hang themselves, stab themselves, drown in the waters.
All the devils are raging in our places. Bishop Sodomus of Merseburg, while visiting the churches to preach, was suddenly struck by dysentery and is gravely ill."
You will learn more from the courier, who will tell various stories about that siege. The pious men resist bravely.
What is happening at the Diet in Baden? Gumpenberg will undoubtedly disturb our people, and the ecclesiastical goods will eventually, God forbid, bring us great harm.
I also wish to know whether you will publish anything this summer and what thoughts you currently have that you intend to make public. Farewell. Basel, June 20, 1551.
Greet D. Theodor in my name, to whom I will write shortly, as soon as I receive letters from Strasbourg, which I am expecting at any moment about various matters.

In Hesse, not to overlook this, the preaching of the Gospel is still heard very clearly, and scarcely 8 can be found in that entire region who would be sent. The prince is still held in very harsh captivity.
To the honorable master Heinrich Bullinger, pastor of the church in Zurich, my gracious lord, to his hands. Zurich.
